data.title: [Windows] Terminal view content isn't correctly placed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.12.0-insider (6c5926309d821ce767743c8166ec225fbe9456ef, 2017-04-21T06:12:00.370Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.12.0|
|vscode-csscomb|mrmlnc|4.0.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.5.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any terminal (Command Prompt, PowerShell, WSL Bash)

    Lines don't start in first column but cursor seems correctly located according to a "normal" display

2. Enters `git` command

    Next prompt display is ok

3. Enters another command (for example : dir or ls)

   Display is broken again

Notes: Tested on Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z) and it works like a charm.

Examples ($ => cursor location):

Command Prompt
```text
Microsoft Windows [version 10.0.15063]
(c) 2017 Microsoft Corporation. Tous droits réservés.
                                                                                                                                                                                         D:
\dev>  $
```

PowerShell
```text
Windows PowerShell
Copyright (C) 2016 Microsoft Corporation. Tous droits réservés.
                                                                                                                                                                                         PS
 D:\dev>yarn                                                                                                                                        ya
rn : Le terme «yarn» n'est pas reconnu comme nom d'applet de commande, fonction, fichier de script ou programme exécutable. Vérifiez l'orthographe du nom, ou si un chemin d'accès  existe,
 vérifiez que le chemin d'accès est correct et réessayez.                                                                                                                        Au caractè
re Ligne:1 : 1                                                                                                                                                                  + yarn
                                                                                                                                                                                + ~~~~
                                                                                                                                                                                    + Categ
oryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (yarn:String) [], CommandNotFoundException                                                                                                       + Fully
QualifiedErrorId : CommandNotFoundException
                                                                                                                                                                                PS D:\dev>             $
```

data.title: Flicker during side-by-side markdown editing/previewing
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.11.2 (1.11.2)
- OS Version: Mac OS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new markdown file
2. Edit it and get some content so that you have a good preview
3. Open a preview window and split the view so you can see what you're editing side by side with the preview
4. Experience visual discomfort, a.k.a., "flicker"

See video below demonstrating the experience.

[![IMAGE ALT TEXT HERE](https://img.youtube.com/vi/NLesTwh-NRI/0.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLesTwh-NRI)

data.title: Configurable MAX_IMAGE_SIZE
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu

In [this line](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/base/browser/ui/resourceviewer/resourceViewer.ts#L112), the size of image is limited to 1MB. This is too small. As in the comment in that line, showing images may consume too much resources. However, if resource is not a problem (e.g., 32 core and 512G mem), could it able to utilize these resources to show large size images (e.g., a 20M gif)?

So this is a feature request. A configurable ``MAX_IMAGE_SIZE`` is great. Thanks!

data.title: vscode open a symbol link folder will redirect to the true path.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T07:56:42.517Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.11|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.14.1|
|code-gnu-global|austin|0.2.1|
|lualinter|dcr30|1.0.3|
|vscode-yaml-validation|djabraham|0.0.1|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.5|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.8|
|Lua|keyring|0.0.9|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.59|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.5.3|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.10.4|
|vscode-hexdump|slevesque|1.2.1|
|rst-vscode|tht13|1.3.0|
|vscode-apielements|vncz|0.6.0|
|lua-for-vscode|xxxg0001|0.0.23|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. make a symbol link folder
```
ln -s /home/ch/true_folder /tmp/true_folder
```
2. open folder "/tmp/true_folder"
3. open a terminal in vscode, execute command pwd, which output is:
```
/home/ch/true_folder
```
I think the right output should be "/tmp/true_folder". if not ,it will affect some commands that depend on the current work directory.

data.title: Shortcut Stopped Working After Last Update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.3|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|vscode-sort|henriiik|0.2.5|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|CSSfmt|ilich8086|0.0.3|
|MagicPython|magicstack|1.0.9|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.8.1|
|python|tht13|0.2.3|;


---
keybindings.json:
`[
    {
    "key": "ctrl+shift+w",
    "command": "workbench.action.tasks.runTask",
    "args": "nws"
    }
]`

This shortcut worked prior to the last update. Now it does nothing. I've tried disabling all extensions - still does not work anymore.  When I type Ctrl+Shift+P, T, I can see that Tasks: Run Task is assigned to Ctrl+Shift+W

This task references [https://www.npmjs.com/package/nws](nws) package. I can successfully execute the command from the integrated terminal.

Has something changed in the bindings definitions or is this a bug?

milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version:Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
2.
```
<script>
  export default {
    name: 'app'
  };

</script>
<style scoped>
  .main {
    max-width: 580px;
  }
</style>
```
Whether it can be formated:
```
<script>
export default {
  name: 'app'
};

</script>
<style scoped>
.main {
  max-width: 580px;
}
</style>
```
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11707936/25261030/8e45f91e-2682-11e7-80a9-42c7ff7cbbe0.png)

data.title: Add Setting to Enable JavaScript TypeChecking Checking in Implicit Projects By Default
data.body:
With TS 2.3.1, the new `checkJS` option allows TypeScript to perform some typechecking on javascript files. Users must currently opt into this either by setting `checkJS` in their `jsconfig.json` or `tsconfig.json`, or by adding a `// @ts-check` comment to the top of their file

**Proposal**
To make it easier for users to get started with this setting without creating a `jsconfig.json`, add a new setting called `javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJS` or something similar that opts js files in implicit projects (i.e. those without a jsconfig) into the new type checking logic

data.title: Add setting to disable NPM Not installed Warning Message
data.body:
Fixes #25063 

**Bug**
When a user does not have npm installed, in ts 2.3.1, we show a warning message. This may annoy users in cases where we just cannot find npm but it is installed using nvm or n.

I've also opened https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/15287 on TypeScript to discuss how we can handle these cases better

**Fix**
To avoid too much annoyance, add a setting to suppress this warning

data.title: Keyboard keys stop working when I change the user and workspace settings!
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600  (Windows 8.1)
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-javascript-snippet-pack|akamud|0.1.5|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.1.1|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.8|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|vue|jcbuisson|0.1.5|
|theme-material-theme|jprestidge|1.0.1|
|HTMLHint|mkaufman|0.3.3|

|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.0.3|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.When I opened the file "settings.json" and copied some default settings  from  the left  to  the right  ,  than I tried to change them , but I found that they didn't work !  (User and Workspace Settings have the same result)　I realized that many keyboard keys (e.g.  A~Z  、 Enter Backspace  、Small digital keyboard) and shortcut keys(e.g.  ctrl+c 、  ctrl+v ) didn't work.  And sometimes I found some keyboard keys disable when I tried to test the effect descripted by the offical documents.  Hoping for help,thanks!

data.title: Suggestions in comments on trigger characters despite setting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install C# extension
2. Set:

```
"editor.quickSuggestions": {
    "other": true,
    "comments": false,
    "strings": false
  },
```

3. In .cs file write a block comment like this:

```
/// <summary
/// Checks that Index method returns proper model and status codes.
/// </summary>
```

4. Put dot in comment (at the end)

### Expected

Nothing shows up

### Actual

Silly suggestion (`!--`) shows up

data.title: VS Code handles some characters incorrectly for Powershell script files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code or the Powershell extension incorrectly handles some characters that are valid in Windows Powershell ISE and Powershell executable.

I had a script which possibly contained lines of code copy-pasted from a browser.  This worked fine in SIE and executed fine in powershell.  But when I opened the file in VS Code it didn't interpreted the characters correctly and corrupted the file when saved.

I opened the file in a hex editor and found the offending characters:
Left single quotation mark 0x91
Right single quotation mark 0x92
En dash 0x96
Using this as a reference: http://www.character-code.com/

Possibly more but this is all that was wrong with my script.

I realize it's not best practice to use these characters in a script, but they do work fine when edited and executed in Powershell.

***** PLEASE RENAME THE ATTACHED FILE TO .ZIP *****
---

Steps to Reproduce:


1.  Execute the attached file in Pwoershell, no errors
2. Load the attached file in Powershell ISE, you can see the characters are different but they're intercepted correctly
3. Load the same script in VS Code.  It will show the unrecognized character <?>  icon for them.  
4. Save the file in VS Code.  It has replaced the characters and the script will now produce errors.


![vscodepsscriptcharerror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1031627/25257278/b8cd841e-25eb-11e7-8c0b-a0fa4fac4149.png)

data.title: Exception Peek UI should be placed on the top frame with source
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new .NET Core project (ex: `dotnet new console` + `dotnet restore`)
2. Open the project in VS Code + C# extension
3. Add a line that will throw an exception from non-user code. For a trivial example add `String.Format(null, 12)` as the first line of main.
4. Start debugging

Result: 
Debugger will break on the exception, but it will not be clear where or why as VS Code will not bring up the top-most document that has source.

Expected:
VS Code should walk the frames of the stack and choose the first that has a `source` property. VS Code used to do this.

Example json response to the `stackTrace` command:

```json
{
    "seq":29,
    "type":"response",
    "request_seq":11,
    "success":true,
    "command":"stackTrace",
    "message":"",
    "body":{
        "stackFrames": [
            {"id":1000,"name":"[External Code]","line":0,"column":0},
            {
                "id":1001,
                "name":"clicon.dll!Program.Main(string[] args) Line 14",
                "source": {
                    "name":"Program.cs",
                    "path":"d:\\proj\\clicon\\Program.cs",
                    "sourceReference":0,
                    "checksums":[{"algorithm":"SHA1","checksum":"7241f6d2a81d39115752953170fa4e9391d5fcf0"}]
                },
                "line":14,
                "column":9,
                "endLine":14,
                "endColumn":33,
                "moduleId":"{7C382E61-E5C4-49EC-A609-69A65BF4E458}"
            },
            {"id":1002,"name":"[External Code]","line":0,"column":0}
        ],
        "totalFrames":3
    }
}
```

data.title: No IntelliSense for Node modules like `path` when using `let Path = require('path')`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4
- Node version: v.7.9.0
- npm version: 4.2.0

Steps to Reproduce:

````
mkdir test
````

Create `package.json` and run `npm i`:

````
{
  "name": "test",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "devDependencies": {
    "typescript": "2.2.2"
    , "electron": "1.6.2"
    , "@types/electron": "1.4.37"
  }
}
````

Create `tsconig.json`:

````
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "module": "commonjs",
        "target": "es5",
        "noImplicitAny": false,
        "sourceMap": false
    }
}
````

Create `Main.ts`:
````
/// <reference types="node" />

let reqPath = require('path');
reqPath.

import impPath = require('path');
impPath.
````

Problem:
Hitting `Ctrl+Space` on `reqPath.|`shows no suitable suggestions but doing the same on `impPath.|` does:

![reqpath](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6379696/25254716/46489064-2627-11e7-9acb-f6b71fc76386.png)

![imppath](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6379696/25254719/4cc8db24-2627-11e7-97fe-7a9f72fc9421.png)

data.title: Empty arguments in launch commands are now properly escaped
data.body:
Bug discovered with [Python debugger extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=donjayamanne.python). Usually, it passes `debugOptions` array to its python counterpart `visualstudio_py_launcher.py` from `launch.json`, joined with comma, like so:

**launch.json**:
`"debugOptions": ["WaitOnAbnormalExit","WaitOnNormalExit"]`

**launch command**:

> python C:\Users\...\.vscode\extensions\donjayamanne.python-0.6.3\pythonFiles\PythonTools\visualstudio_py_launcher.py working_dir 51686 34806ad9-833a-45248cd6-18ca4aa74f14 **WaitOnAbnormalExit,WaitOnNormalExit** file.py

 However, when `debugOptions` is empty, no argument is passed. As `visualstudio_py_launcher.py` relies on position of its arguments, it breaks, as `file.py` is now taking place of `debugOptions`.

I tracked this issue to `TerminalSupport.prepareCommand` not properly escaping empty argument: it should pass `""` instead of empty string for it.

With this fix, launch command for empty `debugOptions` looks like:

> python C:\Users\...\.vscode\extensions\donjayamanne.python-0.6.3\pythonFiles\PythonTools\visualstudio_py_launcher.py working_dir 51686 34806ad9-833a-45248cd6-18ca4aa74f14 **""** file.py

and successfully works.

Tested only with `cmd.exe`, but in my understanding should be the same for other shells, so I changed that too.

data.title: Treat folds the same as normal lines for cursor movement
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update

The bug I'm experiencing has two parts:
1. When moving down using the down commands (vim `j` in normal mode, or keyboard down arrow in insert mode), the cursor is moved to the end of the line (the fold marker) for lines which have a fold.
2. When the cursor is left on a fold marker for longer than a few hundred milliseconds, the fold expands.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a fold
2. Starting from the top line of the fold, move the cursor down with the keyboard (I moved it down twice in the gifs)

## Expected Result
The cursor treats folded lines as it treats any other lines (you can move up, down over a folded group as though they were all a single line)

Here's the expected behavior, in atom (I apologize for my poor gif quality):
![atom fold](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3342777/25251472/19d5e9ca-25df-11e7-8c19-f0b0d4fcb121.gif)

## Actual Result
Hitting down moves the cursor to the end of the line, atop the fold indicator.
The fold expands.

Here's the actual behavior, in VS Code:
![fold](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3342777/25251488/248452da-25df-11e7-9549-f455cb27281d.gif)

## Notes
I'm using the vim extension in VS Code and vim-mode-plus in Atom. In both cases, it doesn't matter whether I use `j` or `down arrow`.
I'd love to see a setting to disable the auto fold expansion, assuming it's working as designed. I'd much rather toggle the fold myself with a keybinding.
I'd also love to see a toggle fold command. It appears VS Code only has expand and collapse commands.
